Catalyst mass – 1 g, reactant mass – 6 g, solvent (decalin) mass – 80 g, T=280 °С, pH2=40 bar, stirring rate – 900 RPM. C) and D – LaAc:Ani=(50 %wt.:50 %wt.); E) and F) – LaAc:Ani=(20 %wt.:80 %wt.). The co-hydroconversion of lauric acid and anisole was carried out over Ni and NiMo catalysts T=260 and 280 °C and pH2=40 bar. Ni/Al2O3 demonstrated a high activity in converting anisole to cyclohexane, but lauric acid conversion was suppressed over this catalyst. In the co-conversion of their mixture the phenolic had no effect on the conversion of the acid, but the latter prevented the cleavage of the C-O bond in both anisole and reaction intermediates. It was assumed that the successful conversion of anisole in its mixture with lauric acid required that a catalyst should provide the fast consumption of the acid component. Accordingly, NiMo/Al2O3 possessed a high activity in lauric acid conversion, and a high cyclohexane yield from anisole was observed after the complete consumption of the acid. The results of the present study can be useful for the rational design of a catalyst for the effective hydroconversion of bio-oil. Graphical Abstract Keywords Lauric acid Anisole NiMo catalyst Hydrodeoxygenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The sustainable development of modern society and the increase in human life standards require a significant growth in energy supply [1,2]. Up to now, fossil fuels are still the most common and convenient affordable source of energy. Nonetheless, most of the national and international policies declared their aim to achieve net-zero carbon emissions (as CO2), i.e. to be climate neutral by 2050–2070 [3,4]. Achieving such a challenging goal both technically and economically is seen as an essential prerequisite for a successful struggle with the so-called climate change. It follows the findings that the use of fossil fuels is responsible for the increase in harmful emissions into the atmosphere. Consequently, new technologies are being developed for using the renewable energy sources, with biomass being in the spot-light as the only renewable source of carbon together with CO2. Despite the remarkable results in the development of technologies based on the use of electricity or hydrogen, particularly for mobility applications [5,6], a sustainable and efficient production of these energy sources is still far from its widespread implementation. Therefore, energy sources made from various types of biomass, so-called biofuels, now appear to be a more effective way to prevent the uncontrolled accumulation of CO2 in atmosphere [7,8]. The biofuels do not release fossil-stored carbon dioxide, so they are considered as a green alternative to petroleum derivatives that can be easily used within the current transportation infrastructure. The production of bio-derived fuels from vegetable oils, i.e. triglycerides of fatty acids, has already been realized on an industrial scale. The vegetable oils are widely used oils to produce biodiesel, i.e. fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) [9], and hydrotreated vegetable oils (HVO) first commercialized in 2007 [10,11]. Triglycerides are, however, a not-so-abundant and a rather costly resource. Hence, a lot of attention is turned to lignocellulosic biomass. It can be converted into so-called “bio-oils”, which are obtained by fast pyrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass including wood, forestry and agricultural residues. Unfortunately, the produced bio-oils are very complex mixtures of oxygenated compounds formed during the decomposition of lignin and (hemi-)cellulose. The main components of these mixtures include phenols, furans, acids, esters, ethers, alcohols, aldehydes and ketones [11,12] with total oxygen content reaching 40–50 %wt. The wide reactivity range of these compounds makes their upgrading into final products, mainly biofuels, very challenging. A mild hydro-treating step in presence of appropriate catalysts transforms the constituent components of bio-oil, improves the chemical stability of the product and decreases its oxygen content. Nevertheless, only partial deoxygenation is achieved and further hydrodeoxygenation is thus a necessary step to upgrade bio-oils into biocomponents compatible with motor fuels. Wastewater sewage sludge (SS) is also considered as an attractive feedstock for the fuel and energy sector with a growing potential as its production is expected to grow in future [13–15] The collected SS has a high content of organic components represented by carbohydrates, acids, proteins, fats, lignin, tannins, etc. [14,15], and, similar to lignocellulosic biomass, the pyrolysis of SS followed by hydrotreatment of the produced SS-pyrolysis oils is necessary for the integration of the wastewater feedstock in the fuel and energy sectors [15–17]. Aliphatic acids with different carbon chain lengths and phenolic compounds are among the main components of pyrolysis bio-oils and similar mixtures. This makes them good model substrates for identifying optimal reaction conditions and testing the properties of various catalysts [18–21]. According to a generally accepted reaction scheme, the hydroconversion of an acid with n carbon atoms begins with its hydrogenation into the corresponding aldehyde [19–23]. The formed aldehyde can form a hydrocarbon with n-1 carbon atoms in the chain by a decarbonylation (DCO) step, or it is further hydrogenated to the corresponding alcohol ( Scheme 1A). The latter forms a hydrocarbon with n carbon atoms in the chain by a hydrodehydration (HDO) step. Besides, the direct conversion of acids to n-1 hydrocarbons either by a decarboxylation route (DCX) [23] or by a sequential dehydration−decarbonylation (DEC) pathway [24,25] was also described. Additionally, an interaction between the original acid with the resulting alcohol gives an ester [18,26]. The hydroconversion of phenolic compounds proceeds through several parallel/consecutive hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis steps, including the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, demethylation and demethoxylation steps, as well as dehydration/hydrogenation of intermediate cyclic alcohols [27–33] (Scheme 1B). Additionally, both a feedstock substrate and reaction intermediates can participate in transalkylation, esterification and other reactions. A preferential reaction route and the composition of reaction products depend, as in the case of the conversion of a carboxylic acid, on the reaction conditions used and the properties of the catalyst chosen. Despite there are numerous studies on hydrodeoxygenation of both aliphatic acids and phenolics, their co-conversion has not been reported so far. Nonetheless, both of these compounds are present in lignocellulosic bio-oils [11,12] and SS-pyrolysis oils [14,15]. As a result, their simultaneous transformation on the same catalyst under the same reaction conditions is of interest to shed light on plausible inhibiting effects that the components of the mixture could introduce on each other’s conversion. The present work deals with the conversion of lauric acid and anisole, both individually and in their mixture, over Ni/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/Al2O3 catalysts that differ in both the metal function and the support properties. The results demonstrate that the acid introduces a significant deactivating effect on the HDO of anisole to cyclohexane by the inhibition of a C-O bond cleavage. While the deactivating effect of anisole on the hydroconversion of lauric acid is minor and mostly expressed in changing the contribution of DCO/HDO steps to produce hydrocarbons. The results can thus be used for a rational development of catalysts for the hydroconversion of real bio-oils and SS-pyrolysis oils and for the optimization of reaction conditions for these processes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The catalysts were prepared by a wet impregnation method using Al2O3 (Pural) or SiO2 (fumed silica, Sigma-Aldrich) as supports and the aqueous solutions of Ni nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O, 99 %, Penta s.r.o., Czech Republic) and ammonium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24, LacnNer s.r.o., Czech Republic) taken in necessary amounts to reach 12 wt% Ni or 12 wt% Ni+7 wt% Mo loading in the final catalysts. The wet impregnation procedure was performed using a laboratory vacuum rotary evaporator (IKA RV3/HB eco, Germany). The impregnated powders were dried for 12 h at room temperature and then for 12 h at 60 °C. The as-prepared supported catalysts were then calcined in static air at 350 °C for 3 h in a muffle oven to decompose the salts. The calcined samples were reduced in a H2 flow (99.9 %, SIAD Czech, s.r.o., Czech Republic) at T=480 °C in a Parr stainless steel autoclave with a reactor volume of 300 mL. The samples were denoted as Me/Support-X, where Me was Ni or NiMo, support was Al2O3 or SiO2, and X showed the state of the catalyst, i.e. either as-prepared (AP), or calcined (C) or reduced (R). 2.2 Physico-chemical characterization The phase composition of the as-prepared, calcined and spent samples was determined by X-Ray diffraction using a diffractometer PANanalytical X’Pert3 Powder and CuKα radiation. The XRD patterns were recorded in a range of 2θ=5–70°. The content of Ni and Mo in the samples was determined by XRF using a spectrometer ARL 9400 XP equipped with a rhodium lamp (Thermo ARL, Ecublens, Switzerland). Equilibrium nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured at 77 K using a static volumetric adsorption system (TriFlex analyzer, Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, USA). The samples were degassed at 473 K (12 h) prior to the N2 adsorption analysis in order to obtain a clean surface. The adsorption isotherms were fitted using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method to determine the specific surface area. The reducibility of the calcined samples was determined by Quantachrome ChemStar TPx instrument with a TCD detector. The samples were exposed to a reducing gas mixture containing 10 vol% of hydrogen in argon with a flow of 50 mL·min−1. A U-shaped reactor with a sample (typically 0.1 g) was located in a furnace and treated with the reducing gas at a heating rate of 5 °C·min−1 from room temperature up to 900 °C. The number of acid and base sites in the reduced samples was determined by TPD of adsorbed pyridine and CO2, respectively, using Micromeritics Instrument (AutoChem II 2920). The detection of desorbed pyridine and CO2 was performed using a thermal conductivity detector and a quadrupole mass spectrometer (MKS Cirrus 2 Analyzer). The details of both pretreatment and adsorption/desorption procedures were described in our previous articles [34,35]. 2.3 Catalyst testing All catalytic experiments were carried out in a Parr stainless steel autoclave with a reactor volume of 300 mL. Lauric acid (LaAc, Aldrich, ≥98 %) and anisole (Ani, Aldrich, 99 %) were used as reactants, decalin (mixture of cis- and trans isomers, Sigma-Aldrich) was used as a solvent and n-decane (Sigma-Aldrich) was used as an internal standard. In an additional test, lauryl laurate (LaLa, prepared by a method described in [18]) was also used as a reactant. Before a catalytic experiment, a calcined catalyst (m=1.0 g) was loaded into the autoclave and reduced in situ at 480 °C using H2 (99.9 %, SIAD Czech, s.r.o., Czech Republic) for 1 hour. After the reduction step and autoclave cooling, a reaction mixture consisting of 6 g of a reactant dissolved in 80 g of decalin and 1 g of the internal standard was loaded into the reactor. The filled reactor was flushed with the flow of hydrogen for 30 minutes. Then, the gas flow was stopped and the reactor was heated up to the required temperature. After reaching the reaction temperature, the reaction pressure was adjusted to 40 bar. The effect of both internal and external diffusion was evaluated by performing catalytic experiments with varying stirring rate and catalyst weight. Based on these results, the stirring rate was kept at 900 RPM. Liquid reaction products were periodically (5, 10, 20, 40, 60, 90, 120, 180 min) withdrawn from the reactor during the experiment, diluted with acetone (1:25 V/V) and analysed by an Agilent 7820 GC-FID using a HP-5 capillary column, 30 m length, 0.32 mm i.d., 0.25 μm thick. Catalytic results were described by the residual content of a reactant in a reaction mixture and the yield of a reaction product and calculated as follows: The residual content of a reactant at time (t) (% mol.)=100 × (mole of a reactant present in reaction mixturet=t)/(mole of a reactantt=0); The yield of a component (i) at time (t) (% mol.)=100 × (mole of a reactant converted to a component it=t)/(mole of a reactant t=0), where t stands for reaction time. Each catalytic experiment was repeated 2–3 times to prove the reproducibility of the obtained results (with an experimental error evaluated as ±5 % relative). Mass balance evaluated by the internal standard was above 96 % in all experiments. 3 Results 3.1 Chemical analysis Table 1S (in the Supplementary information, SI) presents the chemical composition of the calcined samples. The results showed that the actual content of Ni or Mo in the solids corresponded to the targeted values. 3.2 XRD Fig. 1S (see the Supplementary information) depicts the XRD patterns of the as-prepared, calcined and reduced Ni/Al2O3, Ni/SiO2 and NiMo/Al2O3 samples. Apart from reflections of the γ-Al2O3 support, XRD patterns of the as-prepared Ni/Al2O3-AP and NiMo/Al2O3-AP samples demonstrated small reflections from Ni and Mo salts or a mixed NiMo phase(s) loaded on the support. The XRD pattern of the calcined Ni/Al2O3-C and NiMo/Al2O3-C evidenced presence of well-dispersed NiO phase only with the size of about 13 nm. After the reduction of the Ni/Al2O3-C and NiMo/Al2O3-C samples, the reflections from the NiO particles disappeared, and the reflections from metallic Ni species with the size of about 12.6 nm appeared instead. In total, the existence of small and broad reflections from Ni species in the XRD patterns of both Ni/Al2O3-R and NiMo/Al2O3-R samples allowed assuming the formation of numerous surface species possibly formed as the result of a strong interaction between Ni (or NiMo) species and the Al2O3 support. The XRD pattern of the as-prepared Ni/SiO2-AP sample showed only a broad signal centered at ≈22° from SiO2 (Fig. 1S in the SI) suggesting a good dispersion of Ni nitrate species on the surface of the support. The calcination of the as-prepared precursor resulted in the formation of NiO species in the Ni/SiO2-C sample with the size of about 24 nm, i.e. larger than those in the Ni/Al2O3-C. After the reduction of the Ni/SiO2-C sample the metallic Ni particle size with the size of 19 nm were formed in the Ni/SiO2-R sample. This evidenced that, similar to Ni/Al2O3-R, no sintering of Ni species occurred during the reduction step. 3.3 N2 physisorption Table 1S depicts results on the textural characteristics of all samples. The value of BET area of the parent as-received alumina support was 274 m2/g. The loading of Ni nitrate on the support resulted in a substantial drop in the BET area in Ni/Al2O3-AP. The values of both BET surface and pore volume were larger in the calcined Ni/Al2O3-C and reduced Ni/Al2O3-R samples, and virtually no difference was observed between the textural properties of the calcined and reduced samples (Table 1S). A similar effect of the metal loading on the Al2O3 support, as well as of the calcination and reduction steps on the textural properties of the resulting samples was observed in case in NiMo catalysts, and the addition of Mo to Ni had only a limited impact on the textural properties of the resulting samples (Table 1S). The value of BET area of the parent as-received silica support was 372 m2/g, and the effect of Ni loading on the BET surface and pore volume of the prepared samples was even more pronounced (Table 1S). The results prove that the loading of Ni and Mo significantly affected the textural characteristics of the Al2O3 and SiO2 supports due to partial blocking of their porous space with metal particles. 3.4 H2-TPR The H2-TPR profile of Ni/Al2O3-C exhibited a very distinctive peak in a low-temperature region with a maximum at around 300 °C ( Fig. 1) that can be ascribed to the reduction of nickel oxide (Ni2+ → Ni0) interacting weakly with the Al2O3 support [36,37]. A broad signal with a complex shape located in the high-temperature region above 350 °C can be assigned to the reduction of NiO particles interacting strongly with the support [36] as well as to the reduction of a NiAl spinel phase with the general formula of NiAlxOy (where x ≥2 and y≥4), as reported in [38,39]. The shape of the H2-TPR profile for the NiMo/Al2O3-C sample was also rather complicated (Fig. 1), and it included signals from the reduction of both NiO/NiAlxOy and MoO3/NiMoO4/ Al2(MoO4)3 phases. Because of that, it is virtually impossible to assign accurately the TPR peaks as it is hard to distinguish the contribution of Ni and Mo species due to the extensive overlap of the individual peaks in the overall H2-TPR profile [40]. Nevertheless, some general conclusions could be made. The intensity of the low-temperature NiO reduction peak at around 300 °C decreased in the NiMo/Al2O3-C sample in comparison with Ni/Al2O3-C (Fig. 1). This could be attributed by the existence of a close contact between Ni and Mo particles, what shifted the low-temperature peak to the high-temperature region. A similar effect of Mo presence in NiMo catalysts on the intensity of the low-temperature peak in a H2-TPR profile was observed also by Kumar et al. [41]. At the same time, a new distinctive peak appeared in the region of 340–370 °C, which could be associated with the partial reduction of MoO3 to MoO2 [41–43]. Besides, the reduction of NiMoO4 species was also reported in the same temperature region [40]. In the range of 400–500 °C, the area of peaks in the profile of the NiMo/Al2O3-C sample was larger than in the Mo-free Ni/Al2O3-C sample. This indicates that in addition to NiO strongly interacting with Al2O3 and NiAlxOy phases, Mo species were reduced as well. This could include the reduction of MoO2 species to metallic Mo together with highly dispersed tetrahedral Mo species or those strongly bonded to the alumina support [41–43]. The broad peak observed in the profile of NiMo/Al2O3-C above 700 °C could correspond to the reduction of highly dispersed Al2(MoO4)3 species [41,42]. The H2-TPR profile of Ni/SiO2-C sample exhibited a small peak at around 220 °C and a sharp big peak centered at 340 °C (Fig. 1). According to [44,45], the low-temperature small peak demonstrated the phase transition and a partial reduction of NiO species, while the intensive peak indicated the complete reduction of the large NiO crystallites interacting weakly with the support. Additionally, a small shoulder in the range of 400 °C could be attributed to the reduction of small NiO particles interacting strongly with the support or to the nickel silicate species [44,45]. Considering the metal content in the samples, the overall H2 consumption was above 95 % of the theoretical H2 consumption for both Ni/Al2O3-C and Ni/SiO2-C, thus evidencing an almost complete Ni reduction during the H2-TPR study. In case of NiMo/Al2O3-C the overall H2 consumption was about 85 % of the theoretical value. Smirnov et al. [46] showed that the content of Mo° in NiMo-SiO2 samples could reach 100 % only at a reduction temperature of 750 °C. It can be assumed that in our NiMo/Al2O3-C sample with a strong metal-support interaction (stronger than in case of silica-supported oxides) either Mo or NiMo species could remain partially in oxidic state even after the reduction of the sample at 900 °C. 3.5 TPD of adsorbed pyridine and CO2 The acido-basic properties of bare Al2O3 used as a support as well as the reduced Ni/Al2O3-R, NiMo/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R samples were determined by Py-TPD and CO2-TPD. The Py-TPD and CO2-TPD curves for Al2O3, Ni/Al2O3-R and NiMo/Al2O3-R (Fig. 2S in the SI) exhibit peaks centred at about 250 and 150°C, correspondingly. The concentration of acidic and basic sites in the bare Al2O3 was 128 and 50 μmol/g·cat, respectively ( Table 1). The concentration of acidic sites in the Ni/Al2O3-R dropped by approximately two times to 67 μmol/g·cat, possibly due to blocking of the acidic sites of the support. Malaibari, et al. [47] suggested that the impregnation of a γ-Al2O3 with Ni resulted in the decreased acidity of the support. Nevertheless, the concentration of acidic sites in the NiMo/Al2O3-R was higher, 132 μmol/g·cat. This increase in the acidity of the sample could be caused by Mo presence. Indeed, Lowenthal, et al. [48] reported that the amount of acid sites increased markedly upon addition of Mo to the Al2O3 surface. Moreover, it was assumed that MoOx demonstrated a strong Lewis acidity, while NiO was a mild base [47]. The concentration of basic sites in both Al2O3 and Ni/Al2O3-R was similar, 50 and 45 μmol/g·cat, correspondingly, but notably decreased to 9 μmol/g·cat in the NiMo/Al2O3-R, possibly due to the interaction of the acidic Mo species with the basic sites of the support. At the same time, the TPD curves for Ni/SiO2-R did not indicate any signals (Fig. 2S in the SI), therefore it could be concluded that this sample did not demonstrate any acid-base character. 3.6 Catalysis 3.6.1 The hydroconversion of lauric acid and anisole over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R catalysts In preliminary experiments it was found that the bare Al2O3 used as a support for the preparation of catalysts did not possess any activity in both lauric acid and anisole hydroconversion. First, the performance of monometallic Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R catalysts was compared in the hydroconversion of lauric acid (LaAc) and anisole (Ani) as individual compounds at similar reaction conditions. At T=280 °C and pH2=40 bar, the conversion of LaAc over Ni/Al2O3-R occurred at a moderate rate as the residual LaAc content in the reaction mixture was 7 % after three hours ( Fig. 2A). This result agreed well with our recent findings [18]. The performance of Ni/SiO2-R in LaAc hydroconversion was quite similar to that of Ni/Al2O3-R with the residual LaAc content of ≈4 % after 3 hours (Fig. 2B). The similar performance of supported Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R catalysts in the hydroconversion of stearic acid was earlier reported by Kumar, et al. [49]. The performance of both catalysts was evaluated by the initial rate of LaAc consumption (rini-LaAc, mmol·gcat −1·min−1) reported in Table 2. It shows that the rini-LaAc values were very close for these two catalysts being in the range of 0.33–0.35 mmol·gcat −1·min−1. In agreement with the general scheme of aliphatic acid hydroconversion in presence of supported Ni catalysts [18,23–25,49], the hydrogenation of the acid resulted in the formation of the corresponding aldehyde as the primary reaction product, which was then rapidly hydrogenated to the alcohol (Scheme 1A). Here, the yield of lauryl aldehyde (LaAd) among reaction products did not exceed a few tenths of a percent indicating its rapid consumption by subsequent reactions. Among reaction products, lauryl alcohol (LaAl) and lauryl laurate (LaLa) were observed from the very beginning of the experiment (Figs. 2A and 2B). LaAl yield increased to 11 % and 22 % after 60 minutes of reaction over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R catalysts, correspondingly, and further decreased to ≈4 % at the end of the run. The decreased yield of the alcohol in the reaction mixture reflected its consumption by the transesterification route, i.e. its reaction with unreacted LaAc that resulted in the formation of the ester (LaLa). Consequently, the maximum LaLa yield was 28 % and 23 % over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R, correspondingly, after 120 minutes of reaction (Figs. 2A and 2B). The difference in the yield of LaAl and LaLa observed over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R was due to the contribution of Al2O3 as a support possessing acidic properties to the transesterification activity of the Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst, as suggested in [18]. Undecane (C11) was the predominant hydrocarbon product formed over both catalysts by the decarbonylation route from the aldehyde intermediate [18,23,49] (Scheme 1A), and its yield gradually increased to ≈60 % after 3 hours (Figs. 2A and 2B). The yield of dodecane (C12) as another hydrocarbon reaction product formed by LaAl dehydration followed by a rapid hydrogenation of the intermediate olefin was considerably lower, and its yield was below 1 % and near 3 % after 3 hours over 12Ni/Al2O3-R and 12Ni/SiO2-R, correspondingly. Kumar, et al. [49] also reported a slight increase in the content of octadecane from stearic acid observed for Ni/SiO2 in comparison with Ni/Al2O3. Taken together, the catalytic results on the hydroconversion of LaAc over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R catalysts evidenced that the performance of the catalysts was governed by reduced Ni species, while the properties of Al2O3 and SiO2 supports had little effect on LaAc conversion. However, they affected to a small extent the product composition due to the difference in their acid-base properties. Fig. 2C depicts the changes in the product distribution in the conversion of anisole (Ani) over Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst in dependence on the reaction time. In contrast to LaAc, Ani consumption under the same reaction conditions was significantly faster. Already at zero time (when required temperature and pressure values were reached), Ani conversion was 13 % and it increased to 100 % just after 20 minutes. Similar to the experiments with LaAc, the performance of both catalysts in Ani conversion was evaluated by calculating the initial Ani consumption rate (rini-Ani). Table 2 depicts that rini-Ani for Ni/Al2O3-R was 7.58 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, and the comparison of rini values for LaAc and Ani evidenced that Ani was consumed about 20 times faster than LaAc over Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst. Methoxycyclohexane (Mch), cyclohexanol (Col) and cyclohexane (Chn) were the main products of Ani conversion. In addition, benzene, cyclohexanone, methoxycyclohexene, dihexyl ether were also identified among the reaction products, but only in low amounts and at short reaction times, i.e. these were reaction intermediates as were also Col and Mch. A similar composition of reaction products in this reaction was reported repeatedly [27–32]. It is generally accepted that anisole hydroconversion proceeds through several parallel/consecutive hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis steps [27–33,46] (Scheme 1B). Mch is formed by the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring in Ani. The formation of Col occurs either by demethylation of hydrogenation products of anisole, i.e. methoxycyclohexane and methoxycyclohexene, or by direct anisole demethylation to intermediate phenol [31], followed by its hydrogenation (Scheme 1). Indeed, in our experiments methoxycyclohexene was identified among reaction products in amounts below 0.5 % at short reaction times. Intermediate phenol was not detected, thus again, confirming the good hydrogenating properties of Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst. Finally, Chn is produced either directly from anisole by a demethoxylation step, followed by hydrogenation of the formed benzene [29] or by dehydration/hydrogenation of cyclohexanol [28] or by Mch demethoxylation [32] (Scheme 1B). All three main reaction products, Mch, Col and Chn, were produced from the very start of the experiment (Fig. 2C). The maximum yield of Col and Mch was ≈12 % and ≈16 %, respectively, after 10 minutes of the reaction, followed by their gradual decrease. The Chn yield demonstrated two distinct ranges. At short reaction time, the formation of Chn was very fast, and its yield reached 60 % in 10 minutes of the reaction, i.e. to the moment of complete Ani conversion. After that, the growth in Chn yield slowed down reaching the value above 90 % only after 60 minutes. The observed trend in the change in Chn yield with the reaction time allowed us suggesting that, at short reaction time, Chn could be formed directly from Ani by a demethoxylation route through the intermediate benzene followed by its fast hydrogenation, as proposed in [29,46]. Indeed, benzene was identified among reaction products in amounts of 1.5–2 % at short reaction time, thus supporting this suggestion. After complete Ani consumption, Chn was further formed from Mch and Col, but with a slower rate. Similar to Ni/Al2O3-R, Ani conversion over Ni/SiO2-R was very fast with its complete consumption in 10 minutes (Fig. 2D). Correspondingly, the initial Ani consumption rate (rini-Ani) for this catalyst was 7.89 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, i.e. even slightly higher than that for Ni/Al2O3-R (Table 2). This difference cannot be explained by considering only the difference in the size of Ni particles in these catalysts, 12.6 nm and 19 nm, correspondingly (Section 3.2). The results of N2 physisorption could therefore be used to explain the catalytic results. Indeed, the larger BET surface area of the Ni/SiO2-R (160 m2/g, see Table 1S in the SI) could promote better availability of Ni particles in comparison with Ni/Al2O3-R with the BET surface area of 102 m2/g. Additionally, Ni particles in the Ni/Al2O3-R could partially form hardly reducible nickel aluminate species (NiAl2O4), hence they were catalytically inactive. Nevertheless, the distribution of reaction products with the reaction time differed significantly. Mch was the predominant reaction product formed from Ani over Ni/SiO2-R with its maximum content above 70 % after 10 minutes of the reaction (i.e. to the complete Ani conversion), thus evidencing the excellent activity of this catalyst in the hydrogenation of an aromatic ring (Fig. 2D). With the growth in the reaction time, Mch content slowly decreased to 47 % after 180 minutes while the content of both Chn and Col increased, i.e. both compounds were formed from Mch over this catalyst after complete Ani consumption. A trend in the change in Chn content with time was similar (but less expressed) to that observed over Ni/Al2O3-R. It could also be divided in two ranges: Chn fast formation with the content of 20 % after the initial 10 minutes (i.e. to the complete Ani consumption), followed by a moderate growth to 44 % after 180 minutes (Fig. 2D). The composition of reaction mixtures obtained over Ni-R/Al2O3 and Ni-R/SiO2 allowed concluding that a difference in the content of Mch and Chn was a consequence in the ability of these two catalysts to perform the demethoxylation/demethylation+dehydration steps in converting both Ani and Mch molecules. The differences in product distribution observed over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R prompted us to calculate the apparent initial rates of either Mch or Chn formation (Table 2). In this case, a clear dependence on the properties of a support was found. The apparent initial rate of Mch formation (rini-Mch, hydrogenation route) over Ni/Al2O3-R was 1.07 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, while the apparent initial rate of Chn formation (rini-Chn, hydrogenolysis route) was higher, 5.59 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 (Table 2). Consequently, rini-Mch/ rini-Chn ratio that reflects the contribution of the different routes to the reaction products composition was 0.19 for Ni/Al2O3-R. In contrast, the rini-Mch value calculated for Ni/SiO2-R was much larger, 6.08 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, while the rini-Chn value decreased to 1.47 mmol·gcat −1·min−1. Consequently, rini-Mch/ rini-Chn ratio increased to 4.14 for Ni/SiO2-R, i.e. it was 20 times higher in comparison with Ni/Al2O3-R (Table 2). Comparing the results on Ani conversion over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R revealed that both catalysts possessed a comparable performance in the hydrogenation of an aromatic ring (since rini-Ani was comparable for these two catalysts and almost all reaction products were saturated compounds from the very beginning), but different performance in the C-O bond cleavage both in initial Ani and in intermediate Mch, as well as in the dehydration of Col. As a result, the content of formed Chn as the final product of the reaction, differed significantly on these catalysts. Additionally, results from Fig. 2D evidenced that the yield of Col continued to increase even after total Ani consumption, i.e. Col was definitely formed from Mch after complete Ani consumption. In contrast, no unambiguous conclusion could be made on the possibility for Col to be formed from Mch over Ni/Al2O3-R because the yields of both Mch and Col decreased with the increasing reaction time (Fig. 2C). Additional comparative experiments on the conversion of individual Mch and Col over Ni/Al2O3-R showed that the initial conversion of both reactants was rather fast with the initial consumption rate rini-Mch=4.15 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 and rini-Col=5.14 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, correspondingly (Fig. 3S and Table 2S in the SI). Nevertheless, these values were lower than the initial rate of Ani consumption over this catalyst (Table 2). A similarity in the value of consumption rates for Mch and Col supported the suggestion on the direct formation of Col from Ani through intermediate phenol (not observed among the reaction products), because Col was observed among the reaction products of Ani conversion over Ni/Al2O3-R with the maximum yield of 12 % (Fig. 2C). Moreover, an additional experiment on the conversion of a Mch+Col mixture (50 %wt./50 %wt., or 47 %mol./53 %mol.) over this catalyst demonstrated that the calculated initial rate of Mch consumption in its mixture with Col decreased by an order of magnitude, while that of Col consumption in the same experiment decreased less than two times (Fig. 4S and Table 2S in the SI). It allowed suggesting that Col introduced an inhibitory effect on Mch demethoxylation to Chn, and this could explain a slower decrease in the yield of Mch during Ani conversion (Fig. 2C). In contrast to Ni/Al2O3-R, the conversion of Mch and Col over Ni/SiO2-R did not exceed 31 % and 22 %, correspondingly, after 180 minutes of reaction (Fig. 3S and Table 2S in the SI). These experiments showed that the ability of the Ni/SiO2-R catalyst to carry out Mch demethoxylation/demethylation and Col dehydration steps was substantially lower than that of the alumina-supported catalyst. A difference in the distribution of the reaction products observed over Ni/Al2O3-R and Ni/SiO2-R evidenced that the hydrogenation of an aromatic ring and the hydrogenolysis of C–O bond proceed differently. Wen-wu Tang, et al. [50] suggested that the acidity of a catalyst promoted the activation of C-O bond in anisole molecule thus favouring a hydrogenolysis step. A similar synergetic catalytic effect between acid sites and metal sites in supported Ni catalysts for their ability to cleave the C-O bond was reported in other studies [27,51,52]. The Py-TPD data (Fig. 2S in the SI and Table 1) evidence that Ni/Al2O3-R was substantially more acidic than Ni/SiO2-R. Accordingly, the ability of the former catalyst to cleave C-O bonds in both Ani and Mch molecules was more pronounced than that of the latter. Since the ability of a catalyst to cleave C-O bonds is concerned with the acidity of a catalyst, the inhibitory effect of Col on these steps can be explained, for example, by its preferential adsorption on the acid sites of Ni/Al2O3-R that is necessary to dehydrate the alcohol. 3.6.2 The hydroconversion of lauric acid and anisole mixtures over Ni/Al2O3-R After establishing the hydrogenation/deoxygenation of the individual reactants, we focused on their behaviour in a mixture. Preliminary experiments showed that Ni/SiO2-R was poor in Ani hydrodeoxygenation to Chn (Fig. 2D), so the next experiments were carried out with Ni/Al2O3-R only. Herein, the total weight of a reaction mixture was kept constant while the amounts of LaAc and Ani were varied as follows: a) 1.2 g LaAc + 4.8 g Ani (20 %wt./80 %wt. or 12 %mol./88 %mol.), b) 3.0 g LaAc + 3.0 g Ani (50 %wt./50 %wt. or 35 %mol./65 %mol.), and c) 4.8 g LaAc + 1.2 g Ani (80 %wt./20 %wt. or 68 %mol./32 %mol.). An overall change in the composition of the LaAc+Ani reaction mixtures obtained over Ni/Al2O3-R in dependence on reaction time is reported in Fig. 3. A change in the composition of the reaction products formed from LaAc in its mixture with Ani (LaAc:Ani = 80 %wt.:20 %wt.) was rather similar to that observed in the conversion of the acid alone (compare Fig. 2A and Fig. 3A). After 180 minutes of the reaction, the residual acid content was ≈6 %, i.e. slightly less than in the experiment with the LaAc alone, which could be explained by a concentration effect. LaAl and LaLa (with the maximum yield of 9 % and 25 %, respectively) and undecane (with the yield of 62 % at the end of the run) were the main reaction products. Additionally, methyl lauryl ether and methyl laurate (both combined as MeLa) as well as cyclohexyl lauryl ether and cyclohexyl laurate (both combined as HeLa) formed by transesterification/etherification steps between compounds from LaAc and Ani product groups were also identified among the reaction products. A decrease in the LaAc content in the starting LaAc+Ani reaction mixture resulted in a faster consumption of the acid, and, consequently, in a faster C11 formation. Besides, it led also to a decreased yield of LaLa and an increased yield of both MeLa and HeLa (Figs. 3C and 3E). Thus, the addition of Ani to LaAc had no significant (if any) effect on the conversion of the latter over Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst. It resulted in the decrease in LaLa yield at the expense of the formation of additional reaction products. The initial rate of LaAc consumption (rini-LaAc) demonstrated no obvious dependence on the composition of the LaAc+Ani reaction mixture ( Table 3A). This suggested a preferential interaction of the acid with the active sites of the Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst. The conversion of Ani when mixed with a large amount of LaAc (LaAc:Ani = 80 %wt.:20 %wt.) was fast with complete Ani disappearance after 20 minutes (Fig. 3B). Nevertheless, in contrast to the experiment with Ani alone that produced mainly Chn (Fig. 2C), Mch was the main product formed from Ani when mixed with LaAc. The maximum yield of Mch was 82 % after 20 minutes, i.e. to the moment of total Ani conversion, followed by a slow decrease to 65 % after 180 minutes of the reaction. The yield of Chn was 5 % after 5 minutes, followed by a slow increase to 18 % after 180 minutes. Col, dicyclohexyl ether and HeLa were other products of Ani conversion with their yield in the range of 2–9 % (Fig. 3B). As the LaAc:Ani ratio in the initial mixture decreased, a fast Ani conversion was also observed with the predominant formation of Mch with its maximum yield of ≈80 % (Figs. 3D and 3F). With the decreasing LaAc content, a decrease in Mch content and an increase in Chn content with the growth in the reaction time became more evident. Reaction products formed by etherification/transesterification reactions were also formed in experiments with LaAc:Ani= 50:50 and 20:80 (%wt.:%wt.), and these compounds were observed among the reaction products even after 180 minutes. Similar to the experiments above, the performance of Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst in Ani conversion in its mixture with LaAc was characterized by the initial Ani consumption rate (rini-Ani), as well as by the apparent initial rate of Mch and Chn formation (rini-Mch and rini-Chn, correspondingly). Table 3 evidences that rini-Ani value increased from 1.6 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 to 5.41 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 with the decreasing LaAc content in the starting LaAc+Ani mixture. These values were lower than in the experiment with Ani alone (7.58 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, Table 2). This can be explained both by the inhibiting effect of LaAc and by a concentration effect, because the residual Ani content was small already after 5 minutes (Figs. 3B, 3D and 3F). The apparent initial rate of Mch formation increased with the growth in Ani content in the reaction mixture from 1.36 to 4.93 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, which was larger than that in the experiment with Ani alone. In contrast, the apparent initial rate of Chn formation was in the range of 0.13–0.41 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, which was noticeably lower than that in the experiment with Ani alone (5.59 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, Table 2). The rini-Mch/rini-Chn ratio that characterized the contribution of two different routes during Ani conversion, was practically independent on the composition of the starting LaAc+Ani mixture being in the range of 9.9–12 (Table 3), i.e. it was substantially larger than that obtained in the experiment with Ani alone (rini-Mch/rini-Chn=0.19, Table 2). The result suggested that LaAc affected only a little (if at all) the hydrogenation ability of Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst and did not prevent Mch formation from Ani, but it significantly degraded the ability of the catalyst to perform the cleavage of a C–O bond in both Ani and Mch molecules and the dehydration of Col to produce Chn. This conclusion was further supported by additional experiments with both Mch and Col (50 % wt.) mixed with 50 %wt. of LaAc (Fig. 5S in the SI). In this case, the complete conversion of both Mch and Col was not observed even after 180 minutes of the reaction (Fig. 5S(A) and 5 S(B) in the SI, correspondingly), which was substantially longer than in the experiments with individual compounds (Fig. 3S(A) and 3 S(B) in the SI, correspondingly). Moreover, the apparent initial rate of Chn formation (rini-Chn,) from Mch and Col in their mixture with LaAc (50 % wt./50 % wt.) was 0.07 and 0.17 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, correspondingly, which was significantly lower than that obtained in the experiment with LaAc+Ani mixture with the same molar composition (0.34 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, Table 3). In total, the larger the LaAc content in the LaAc+Ani mixture, the larger the residual LaAc content and the larger the residual Mch content after 180 minutes of the reaction over Ni/Al2O3 ( Fig. 4). In other words, the total conversion of the LaAc+Ani mixture to the corresponding hydrocarbons, i.e. to C11 and cyclohexane, is preferred at a decreased LaAc content and increased Ani content in the feed (Fig. 4). It is worth noting that the conversion of Ani in its mixture with LaAc over Ni/Al2O3-R (Figs. 3B, 3D and 3E) was to a large extent similar to the conversion of anisole alone over Ni/SiO2-R (Fig. 2D). The weak hydrogenolysis activity of the latter catalyst was explained by the absence of acid sites in the SiO2 support. In can be, thus, inferred that LaAc in the reaction mixture affected the properties of the Al2O3 support. For example, the adsorption of the acid could prevent the accessibility of the acid sites to anisole and its hydrogenation products, so the hydrogenolysis activity of Ni/Al2O3-R was significantly reduced. An interaction between a carboxylic acid and Al2O3 was reported repeatedly and explained either by a simple adsorption of the acid on the surface of the oxide [53], or by the adsorption of an acid on Al2O3 through electrostatic interactions and hydrogen bonding [54], or by the chemisorption of an acid over the surface of Al2O3 forming nanosized self-assembled structures [55]. Regardless of the type of the interaction between carboxylic acid and Al2O3, it hinders the access of the other reactants to the acid sites on the surface of the support and, therefore, it decreases a possibility for Ani and its hydrogenation products to take part in hydrogenolysis/dehydration steps. As a result, Ani, if mixed with LaAc, was successfully hydrogenated to Mch on Ni sites, but the further conversion of Mch was hindered and could proceed effectively only after total LaAc conversion was reached (Figs. 3D and 3F). On the other hand, no pronounced deactivating effect of Ani on LaAc conversion was found. It allowed concluding that a perspective catalyst for the efficient conversion of the LaAc-Ani mixture has to provide a fast conversion of the acid in order to promote the conversion of Mch formed from Ani to Chn. 3.6.3 The conversion of LaAc and Ani over NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst The benefits of bimetallic non-noble metal catalysts, mostly NiMo catalysts, for the hydrodeoxygenation of carboxylic acids to hydrocarbons were repeatedly reported previously [25,41,56–58]. The positive role of the second component was generally explained by its oxyphilic properties and its ability to modify the electronic properties of the bimetallic active sites that was beneficial for the enhancement of hydrogenolysis, hydrodeoxygenation and hydrogenation steps. The conversion of anisole over NiMo catalysts was also studied [45,59]. Nevertheless, no information is available so far on the performance of equally prepared catalysts in the comparative hydroconversion of a carboxylic acid, anisole and their mixtures at similar reaction conditions. Hence, the performance of NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst was evaluated in the conversion of LaAc, Ani and their mixtures at T=260 °C. A lower reaction temperature of 260 °C (as compared to T=280 °C used in Sections 3.6.1 and 3.6.2) was used in case of the NiMo catalyst due to its higher activity in LaAc hydroconversion. For comparison reasons, the performance of Ni/Al2O3-R at the same reaction temperature was also included here. Predictably, in comparison with the experiment at T=280 °C (Fig. 2A) the conversion of LaAc over monometallic Ni/Al2O3-R at T=260 °C was slower with the LaAc conversion of ≈40 % after 180 minutes and LaLa was the main reaction product ( Fig. 5A). Correspondingly, the calculated initial rate of LaAc consumption decreased from 0.35 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 (Table 2) to 0.16 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 ( Table 4), correspondingly. Compared to the experiment over Ni/Al2O3-R, the conversion of LaAc over NiMo/Al2O3-R at T= 260 °С was very effective with the complete disappearance of the acid in 40–60 minutes (Fig. 5B). Correspondingly, the calculated initial rate of LaAc consumption over this catalyst increased almost 10 times to 1.45 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 (Table 4). The absence of any reflections from Mo species in the XRD patterns of the NiMo/Al2O3 sample (Fig. 1S in the SI), both calcined and reduced, implies that the Mo species were highly dispersed and hence XRD amorphous. In addition, the significant enhancement of the LaAc conversion over NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst (Fig. 5B) indicated that the highly dispersed Mo species were in a close contact with the Ni species promoting their catalytic activity. Indeed, in a comparative experiment, Mo/Al2O3-R catalyst (7 % wt.) prepared by the same synthetic method demonstrated LaAc conversion at T=260 °C below 3 % after 180 min with LaAc as the main reaction product. The low activity of the Mo/Al2O3-R catalyst thus proved the existence of a cooperative effect of both metals in the NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst responsible for the successful LaAc conversion. Moreover, the decrease in the intensity of a low-temperature peak in the H2-TPR profile of the NiMo/Al2O3-R sample allowed suggesting a close contact between the Ni and Mo particles (Fig. 1). The existence of an interaction between Ni and Mo particles in bimetallic NiMo catalysts was proposed in different studies [47,60]. At high LaAc consumption, the LaLa formation in presence of the NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst was significantly restricted, plausibly both due to the lack of the acid for the ester formation and LaLa augmented deoxygenation affording LaAl that was the main reaction product at the beginning of the reaction. Among hydrocarbons obtained over NiMo/Al2O3-R, both C11 and C12 hydrocarbons were present in approximately equal amounts. This can be attributed to a promoted alcohol dehydration (resulting in C12 formation) over bimetallic NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst at the expense of the alcohol/aldehyde decarbonylation route typical for monometallic Ni catalysts leading to C11 hydrocarbons [18,25,41,49]. Similar to the experiment at T=280 °C (Fig. 2B), Ni/Al2O3-R was also very effective in Ani conversion at T=260 °C with total Ani conversion observed in ≈20 minutes (Fig. 5C). The drop in the reaction temperature was reflected in the moderate decrease in the calculated initial rate of Ani consumption from 7.58 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 at T=280 °C (Table 2) to 6.26 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 at T=260 °C (Table 4). A change in the composition of the reaction mixture with the reaction time was also similar at these reaction conditions: Chn was the predominant reaction product from the very beginning of the experiment with the yield above 60 % after 20 minutes. After a complete Ani conversion, Chn was also formed from Mch and Col, but with an obviously slower rate (Fig. 5C). The apparent initial rate of Mch formation (rini-Mch) was 1.18 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 (Table 4), which was very close to that observed at T=280 °C for this catalyst (Table 2), while the apparent initial rate of Chn formation (rini-Chn) decreased from 5.59 to 4.17 mmol·gcat −1·min−1. It suggested that a decrease in the reaction temperature mostly influenced the hydrogenolysis rather than hydrogenation performance of the Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst. This was reflected in a moderate increase in the rini-Mch/rini-Chn ratio from 0.19 to 0.28 at T=280 °C and 260 °C, correspondingly (Tables 2 and 4). In a preliminary experiment, the performance of the Mo/Al2O3-R catalyst (7 % wt.) in anisole hydroconversion was tested. The activity of this catalyst was poor at T=260 °C with anisole conversion below 10 % after 180 minutes of the reaction with phenol and cresol as the main reaction products. Moreover, Saidi, et al. [61] showed that Mo/Al2O3 demonstrated only moderate activity in anisole conversion evet at T=350–450 °C. The total Ani conversion over NiMo/Al2O3-R at T=260 °C was observed in 60 minutes (Fig. 5D), i.e. obviously later than in case of the Mo-free Ni/Al2O3-R (Fig. 5C). Similarly, Zhang, et al. [57] also observed a decrease in guaiacol conversion with the increasing Mo content in NiMo catalysts. In total, the introduction of Mo affected the performance of the resulting NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst in Ani conversion in a different way than the LaAc conversion. While the initial rate of the LaAc consumption increased ≈10 times when adding Mo, the initial rate of Ani consumption decreased about twice, from 6.26 to 3.37 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, for Ni/Al2O3-R and NiMo/Al2O3-R, respectively (Table 4). This could be explained by a close contact between Ni and Mo particles, what influenced the electronic properties of Ni as active sites for anisole hydroconversion [47]. The composition of the reaction products formed from Ani over NiMo/Al2O3-R was similar to that observed for Ni/Al2O3-R (Figs. 5C and 5D) with Chn, Mch and Col observed from the very beginning of the experiment. Nevertheless, the apparent formation rates of these products differed for these two catalysts. As compared with Ni/Al2O3-R, the initial rate of Ani consumption over NiMo/Al2O3-R decreased about twice, from 6.26 to 3.37 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, while the apparent initial rates of Mch and Chn formation over NiMo/Al2O3-R also decreased about twice, from 1.18 to 0.51 mmol·gcat −1·min−1 and from 4.17 to 2.33 mmol·gcat −1·min−1, correspondingly (Table 4). This suggests that the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis performance of NiMo/Al2O3-R was suppressed upon Mo addition in approximately equal degree, which was reflected in the comparable rini-Mch/rini-Chn values, 0.28 and 0.22 for Ni/Al2O3-R and NiMo/Al2O3-R, respectively (Table 4). Comparing the performance of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2 in anisole hydroconversion allowed concluding that this reaction followed a bifunctional catalytic mechanism (metal+acid functionality). The NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst was even more acidic than the Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (Table 1), so the observed decreased ability of the NiMo/Al2O3-R to perform the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring in anisole and to cleave a C-O bond in methoxycyclohexane was not concerned with the change in acidity of the catalysts. Malaibari et al. [47] suggested that MoOx species possess a strong Lewis acidity while NiO is a mild base. This suggestion was in line with our results on the acid-base properties of the prepared samples (Table 1). Nevertheless, it could be assumed that the introduction of Mo changed the nature of acid sites (both their strength and functionality). Moreover, the electronic properties of Mo phases could also affect the electronic state of Ni species [47]. It could be therefore assumed that presence of Mo in the NiMo/Al2O3-R suppressed both hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis performance in anisole conversion by changing both the acido-basic properties and the electronic properties of Ni in this catalyst. In summary, the introduction of Mo species into a supported Ni catalyst significantly promoted LaAc conversion, while it suppressed Ani conversion, which was reflected in the moderately reduced ability of the NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst to carry out the C-O bond cleavage and aromatic ring hydrogenation. Experiments with Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst (see 3.6.2) showed that high Chn yield during LaAc and Ani co-conversion could be possible provided that the inhibition effect of the acid on Ani conversion was compensated by its fast conversion. Therefore, using a NiMo catalyst should have an overall positive effect on the LaAc+Ani co-conversion to produce hydrocarbon products. 3.6.4 The conversion of LaAc + Ani mixture over NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst The performance of NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst was investigated in the conversion of LaAc and Ani mixtures. Different initial LaAc:Ani ratios were investigated, i.e. LaAc:Ani (%wt.:%wt.) was 80:20, 50:50 and 20:80, while the total weight of the reaction mixture was unchanged, i.e. 6 g of the LaAc+Ani mixture per 1 g of the NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst. Accordingly, the number of LaAc and Ani mmoles in the reaction mixture was 24:11, 15:28 and 6:44 (mmol:mmol), i.e. the total number of moles increased with the increasing Ani content. Fig. 6(A-F) depict results on the co-conversion of either LaAc or Ani mixed with its counterpart for different components ratio. As LaAc percentage in the mixture decreased from 80 % to 20 %, the reaction time necessary for the complete conversion of the acid decreased gradually from 60 min (Fig. 6A) to 10 min (Fig. 6E), even though the total moles of oxygenates in reaction mixture increased. LaAl was the main intermediate product of LaAc conversion at the start of the reaction with its maximum yield of 60–65 %, regardless of the LaAc:Ani ratio. The complete disappearance of the alcohol was observed only after 120 minutes, even in the run with low LaAc content in the starting reaction mixture (LaAc:Ani=20:80 (%wt.:%wt.), Fig. 6E). The formation of LaLa by the esterification of LaAc and LaAl also occurred at short reaction time, which was especially evident at the LaAc:Ani ratio of 80:20 (%wt.:%wt.). Methyl laurate and methyl lauryl ether (both marked as MeLa) as well as cyclohexyl laurate and cyclohexyl lauryl ether (both marked as HeLa) formed by the inter-(ester/ether)ification of LaAc and Ani conversion products were the other identified compounds, and their yield increased with the decreasing LaAc content in the reaction mixture (Fig. 6 (A,C and E)). It might be inferred that the formation of both the esters and ethers and their subsequent consumption could explain the slower disappearance of LaAl during the reaction (Fig. 6E) because the alcohol was inevitably formed by these esters/ethers conversion. Additional experiments with LaAc as a reactant demonstrated that, the less acid was taken as a reactant, the faster its total consumption and the faster the intermediate alcohol was consumed (Fig. 6S(A) and (B) in the SI). In turn, experiments with LaAl showed that its conversion also correlated well with the mass of the reactant taken for the tests (Fig. 6S (C) and (D) in the SI). Comparing results on the conversion of either LaAc or LaAl it could be inferred that the acid introduced only a minor inhibiting effect on the conversion of the intermediate alcohol (Fig. 6S in the SI). These results contradicted the fast LaAc conversion and the slow LaAl disappearance during the conversion of LaAl+Ani mixture (Fig. 6(A), (C) and (E)). Additionally, the conversion of LaAl in its mixture with Ani (LaAl:Ani=20:80 (%wt.:%wt.)) was also slower in comparison with the experiment with the same mass of the alcohol taken alone (compare Fig. 6S(D) and Fig. 7S in the SI). This implies that Ani when added to LaAc did not greatly affect the hydrogenation of LaAc to intermediate LaAl, but inhibited the further conversion of the latter, possibly by competing with the alcohol for the same active sites. As the reaction time was extended, hydrocarbons C11 and C12 became the main products of LaAc conversion in its mixture with Ani, but the C11/C12 ratio changed with the change in the initial LaAc:Ani ratio (Fig. 6(A), (C) and (E)). It suggested that the presence of Ani in the reaction mixture influenced the occurrence of DCO and HDO reaction routes during LaAc conversion differently. A detailed discussion on possible reasons for the observed trend in the C11/C12 ratio can be found in the SI. In brief, Rogers and Zheng [62] proposed that the formation of Cn-1 alkane occurred through the dehydrogenation of a Cn aldehyde with the formation of a Cn ketene intermediate, followed by a decarbonylation step and the hydrogenation of the formed Cn-1 olefin. This reaction scheme was later supported by our study [18]. So, the addition of Ani to LaAc could suppress either the dehydrogenation of the intermediate lauric aldehyde, or the decarbonylation of the ketene intermediate, while the formation of C12 product by LaAl dehydration/hydrogenation route remained unaffected. In any case the Ani addition did not prevent the successful conversion of LaAc to C11 and C12 hydrocarbons, but only changed the ratio between these alkanes ( Fig. 7), i.e. the relative rates of the underlying reactions. Time necessary for the complete conversion of Ani mixed with LaAc increased from 40 to 90 minutes with the growth in Ani content from 20 % to 80 % in LaAc+Ani reaction mixture (Fig. 6 (B), (D) and (F)), thus following a concentration effect. The impact of LaAc on Ani conversion became particularly obvious by considering the yield of the reaction products at short reaction time, i.e. when LaAc was present in the reaction mixture. Mch, Col and Chn were formed from the very beginning of the reaction irrespective of the LaAc:Ani ratio in the reaction mixture, and the yield of the reaction products was similar after 10 minutes (Fig. 6 (B), (D) and (F)). In contrast, at this reaction time the yield of Chn was substantially larger and the yield of Mch and Col was lower in the acid-free experiment (Fig. 5D). After 20–40 minutes of the reaction, the yield of both Mch and Col gradually decreased, although the complete conversion of intermediate Mch was not observed even after 180 minutes. The yield of Chn gradually increased and approached ≈100 % after 180 minutes. Additionally, HeLa was also formed as an inter-(ester/ether)ification reaction product with its yield below 1 % in all experiments. Again, the initial rates of LaAc and Ani consumption and the apparent initial rates of Mch and Chn formation were calculated for experiments with LaAc:Ani mixtures over NiMo/Al2O3-R ( Table 5). Here, results obtained for experiments with pure LaAc and Ani were also included for a comparison. The initial rate of LaAc consumption was rather similar in the range of 1.34–1.48 mmol gcat −1 min−1 with the change in the LaAc:Ani ratio from 100:0 to 50:50 (%wt.:%wt.), but it decreased to 0.83 mmol gcat −1 min−1 at the lowest LaAc content in the reaction mixture (Table 5A). This can be explained by an experimental error caused by the small content of the acid in the reaction mixture and, consequently, its fast consumption. The initial rate of Ani consumption showed a definite downward trend with a decrease in the content of this component in the LaAc:Ani reaction mixture (Table 5B). The low content of LaAc in the mixture (LaAc:Ani=20 %wt.:80 %wt.) resulted in the moderate decrease in the initial rate of Ani conversion to 2.94 mmol gcat −1 min−1 in comparison with 3.37 mmol gcat −1 min−1 in the acid-free experiment, but the apparent initial rate of Chn formation declined significantly to 0.68 mmol gcat −1 min−1. Accordingly, the rini-Mchn/rini-Chn value substantially increased from 0.26 in the acid-free experiment to 1.35 in the experiment with LaAc:Ani=20 %wt.:80 %wt. mixture (Table 5B). This evidences that, similar to the experiments on the conversion of LaAc+Ani mixture over Ni/Al2O3-R catalyst (see Section 3.6.2), the acid did not substantially affect the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring in Ani molecule over the NiMo/Al2O3-R but considerably inhibited the cleavage of a C-O bond in both reactant and reaction intermediates. With the further increase in the LaAc/Ani ratio both rini-Mch and rini-Chn decreased equally, so the rini-Mchn/rini-Chn value was in the range of 1.9–2.0. Thus, the results obtained with both catalysts allowed concluding that improved Mch conversion as a reaction intermediate was necessary for the successful complete Ani deoxygenation in its mixture with LaAc. Additional experiments brought more insight into the poor Mch conversion in presence of different oxygenates formed during the conversion of LaAc+Ani over NiMo/Al2O3-R. Indeed, Mch conversion was inhibited by Col, LaAl and LaLa as reaction intermediates (Figs. 9 S and 10 S in the SI). This allowed concluding that Mch conversion as the intermediate of Ani conversion was a key and the most difficult step in the co-conversion of LaAc+Ani mixtures. 3.6.5 The stability of NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst during the conversion of LaAc+Ani reaction mixture The long-term stability of a catalyst is one of the main questions that need to be answered when evaluating its performance. Experiments in a batch stirred reactor described above helped to demonstrate a degree to which the components of LaAc+Ani reaction mixture affect each other's conversion and the distribution of the reaction products. Accordingly, experiments in a flow reactor were intended to evaluate whether the composition of LaAc+Ani reaction mixture affects the long-term performance of the NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst. Fig. 8A depicts the change in the distribution of the reaction products obtained during LaAc conversion in a flow reactor in dependence on time-on-stream (TOS). During 6 hours, the conversion of LaAc was in the range of 84–87 % with a slight decreasing trend. Among the reaction products, the content of LaAl moderately increased from 43.5 % to 47 % at the expense of the content of C11 hydrocarbons that decreased from 20 % to 15 %, while the content of C12 was stable in the range of 14.5–15.5 %. At the beginning of the 6-hour run the content of C11 noticeably prevailed over C12, while at the end both hydrocarbons were produced in approximately equal amounts (Fig. 8A). It was suggested that in the hydroconversion of a carboxylic acid Ni species were mostly responsible for the formation of C(n-1) hydrocarbons via decarbonylation route while Mo species participated in the production of Cn hydrocarbons via dehydration/hydrogenation route [22,23,57]. Fig. 8A thus demonstrates that the performance of the Ni species in LaAc conversion slightly degraded during the reaction while that of the Mo species did not. Ani conversion in flow reaction conditions was efficient, and its conversion was ca. 91 % after 1 hour of TOS with Chn as the main reaction product with the yield of 80 %. At the same time, only small amounts of Mch and Col as reaction intermediates were formed (Fig. 8B). After 6 hours, Ani conversion slightly decreased to 87 %. Simultaneously, Chn yield decreased to 78 %, and the yield of Col and Mch remained practically unchanged, about 4–5 % and 5–6 %, respectively, during the run. Thus, it can be inferred that similar to batch experiments, the conversion of Ani as a sole reactant in a flow reactor mainly proceeded via the cleavage of a C-O bond in both Ani and Mch as well as by the dehydration of Col. The conversion of LaAc in its mixture with Ani (80 %wt.:20 %wt.) in a flow reactor demonstrated a rather stable behaviour (Fig. 8C) and resembled results obtained in the experiment with LaAc alone (Fig. 8A). A slight decrease in LaAc conversion from 84‐87% to 81‐83% could be only mentioned. Among hydrocarbon products, a gradual decrease in the content of C11 during the reaction resulted in the prevalence of C12 over C11 at the end of the experiment. These results agree with those from a batch reactor, and they allow concluding that Ani added to LaAc did not introduce a significant negative effect on the conversion of the carboxylic acid over NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst. Ani conversion in its mixture with LaAc (LaAc:Ani=80 %wt.:20 %wt.) was in the range of 80–85 % during whole run (Fig. 8D), i.e. it slightly dropped in comparison with experiment with Ani alone where the conversion was in the range of 85–90 % (Fig. 8B). Nevertheless, the composition of the reaction products derived from Ani in its mixture with LaAc varied to a large extent from those obtained in the experiment with Ani alone (Figs. 8B and 8D): Chn yield decreased from 77‐80% to 45‐50%, while the content of Col and Mch increased from 5 % to 10–11 % and 20–23 %, respectively (Fig. 8D). Thus, the results on the conversion of Ani in its mixture with LaAc in a flow reactor also agreed with those obtained in a batch reactor and evidenced that LaAc presence reduced the ability of NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst to cleave a C-O bond in Ani and Mch and to perform Col dehydration, while the ability of the catalyst to hydrogenate an aromatic ring was retained. Despite the discovered impact of LaAc on the conversion of Ani, in terms of the overall activity and the composition of the reaction products, the stable performance of NiMo/Al2O3-R catalyst in the 6-hour experiment indicated that the components of the LaAc+Ani mixture during their co-conversion did not introduce any additional deactivating effect on the properties of the catalyst when processing an (acid+phenolic) reaction mixture. Moreover, the characterization of catalysts after reaction proved that neither loss of metal nor changes in the size of metal particles occurred during the catalytic tests, thus also confirming the high stability of the prepared catalysts in the co-conversion of acids and phenolics. 4 Conclusions The experiments on the concurrent conversion of LaAc and Ani in their binary mixtures over Ni/Al2O3 in batch reaction conditions demonstrated that presence of the acid in the mixture introduced an obvious inhibitory effect on the ability of the catalyst to cleave a C-O bond in both the initial Ani and its hydrogenation products, i.e. Mch and Col formed as reaction intermediates. Consequently, the formation of Chn from Ani was strongly suppressed until the complete LaAc consumption. By comparing the performance of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/SiO2 catalysts it was inferred that LaAc interacted with the active sites of the Al2O3 support and suppressed their ability or availability to perform the C-O cleavage steps. On the other hand, Ani did not introduce any inhibitory effect on the acid conversion. The successful co-processing of LaAc and Ani mixtures was more efficient over a NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst with an impressive activity in the conversion of both reactants. In this case, the inhibitory effect of LaAc on the cleavage of a C-O bonds in Ani, Mch, and Col as a crucial step in the total reaction scheme leading to complete deoxygenation was substantially decreased. As a result, hydrocarbons were the only reaction products formed in the conversion of LaAc+Ani mixtures over the NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst. Additionally, Ani present in the reaction mixture influenced the extent of the DCO and HDO routes during LaAc transformation, thus changing the final ratio of C11/C12 hydrocarbons produced. The experiments in flow reaction conditions demonstrated that the inhibitory effect of the unreacted LaAc on the conversion of Ani to Chn was also obvious. Nevertheless, there was not any pronounced deactivation of the NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst during hydroprocessing of the LaAc+Ani mixture. To generalize, a successful catalyst for the conversion of mixtures containing both phenolics and fatty acids needs to possess a high activity in the acid conversion to suppress its inhibitory effect on phenolics conversion. coredata.dc:description: The co-hydroconversion of lauric acid and anisole was carried out over Ni and NiMo catalysts T=260 and 280 °C and pH2=40 bar. Ni/Al2O3 demonstrated a high activity in converting anisole to cyclohexane, but lauric acid conversion was suppressed over this catalyst. In the co-conversion of their mixture the phenolic had no effect on the conversion of the acid, but the latter prevented the cleavage of the C-O bond in both anisole and reaction intermediates. It was assumed that the successful conversion of anisole in its mixture with lauric acid required that a catalyst should provide the fast consumption of the acid component. Accordingly, NiMo/Al2O3 possessed a high activity in lauric acid conversion, and a high cyclohexane yield from anisole was observed after the complete consumption of the acid. The results of the present study can be useful for the rational design of a catalyst for the effective hydroconversion of bio-oil.
